page.title: 01THE ORIGINS OF BRADFORD
page.content: At the time of the original Domesday it was said that{"Ilbert de Lacy hath {it; it is waste." }In 1379 after a plague the population was only 300. It was not until about 1760, with the {Industrial Revolution,}that the town began to grow. Trade developed,a canal and roads were built, & coal and iron works were developed. In 1842 it was described as{"the filthiest and worst {regulated town in the Kingdom." In 1847 Bradford was Incorporated and the Council went on to 'clean up' the squallour - a task which they have continued to the present day. It now has a modern city centre around the splendid historic City Hall. Now a{Metropolitan District,} with a growing population of 454,198 (1981) it is still known as the{"wool capital {of the World."}
